snippet.textDisplay: You are his child. The fact is that you should his first priority. You and everyone else seeks out approval and acceptance from both parental figures. Whether he is in your life or not. I am Christian, I was brought up Christian and you are aloud to have issues with the bible and you are allowed not to agree with parts of it. Because people are living their lives as best they can. You only have one shot at this life and you should live it how you want and do and be what makes you happy. Whoever my kid grows into she's not going to have one doubt about how loved and accepted she is. And I'm sorry that he hasn't been there for you. He is a failure as a parent. You can't put limitations or conditions on your love.

snippet.textDisplay: thank you for that video even if it hurt. /hug/ it helps to know you're not alone in being rejected by a parent, even though it feels a bit like flailing around wildly not knowing what to do or why this is happening (of course we know logically, but emotionally that's what it feels like to me). it's not fair. it really isn't. to anyone in similar hurt (even if different situations), what's helped/still helps me is "Adult Children of Emotionally Immature Parents : How to Heal from Distant, Rejecting, or Self-Involved Parents" by Lindsay Gibson and her sequel "Recovering of Emotionally Immature Parents".

snippet.textDisplay: it is a horrible cult, i absolutely know what you mean. (For me it was not a wedding but a funeral of a beloved family member). Of course, that's not your fault and of course that still hurts. Choosing a "religion" over such an important day is a very sad life choice. However, people like your father are victims too. At a certain point in life, they have lost their footing and they were in desperate need of some carrying community. what they got is an institution that only wanted their money and free work. it's horrible. Wishing you the best marriage ever and wishing your dad, even if the chances are small, that one day he's able to leave this toxic cult behind.

snippet.textDisplay: It always hurts when someone you love, especially family, won’t partake in something important in your life for any reason. I feel for you and I support your message fully. Your worth is not dependent on your family’s views of you and/or your life choices. Everyone walks a different path and it’s not our right to judge that path but it doesn’t stop them from trying. We can’t control what our loved ones think of us but What we can do for ourselves is move on without them which hurts so much but is much more rewarding in the end. I hope you have an amazing wedding day and find the strength to get past this. ❤️❤️❤️🏳️‍🌈

snippet.textDisplay:
Wow, Hannah... it's been a looooong way since "My Drunk Kitchen".

I must confess, I've kinda fallen out of constantly watching your videos lately. Life gets busy, and I'm twice as old as your core audience. I did know you and Ella are engaged, and I saw the "trying on dresses" video.

I'm from an age when two such lovely women as you two would've had to pretend to be "roommates", and couldn't ever have dreamed of marriage. Love is love is love is love is love is love is love...

You two deserve to be happy. You bring such joy to the 'Tube in an era when there's so much meanness and vanity. I can't tell you how many times your delightful goofiness has brightened an otherwise gloomy day. I had a crush on you since I first started watching MDK regularly, but wasn't really surprised when you came out...

Just happy that you get to be you. Sorry your dad is breaking your heart so... hope that, someday, that will mend. In closing, all I really wanna know, I guess, is

Will there be cheese at the reception?

snippet.textDisplay: I’m sorry your dad isn’t who he should be to you. Being 2nd to a parent is never an easy existence. And being 2nd to the Witnesses is never easy either. It took a while to figure out what I wanted to say, what vibes to send in your direction. And I think I’ve figured it out. You are not alone. You aren’t wrong. You and your soon to be wife are gonna be the cutest couple ever. And he’s wrong. And that isn’t your fault. I’ve waited on my dad a thousand times and every time he fails it still hurts. But it’s never your fault. It has never been your fault. It will never be you fault. You are a human being. Loved and deserving of that. No organization or religion gets to say otherwise because the smile on your face when you speak of Ella shows just how much joy you bring to this world. You lend light where ever you go, to all of us you enjoy your content. From a long time fan, I mourn this lost with you.

snippet.textDisplay: I grew up in an abusive religious household and was beaten for being attracted to girls. And eventually I was kicked out onto the street. My heart hurts every day because I never had a mother like other children did. My dad was kept in the dark about what was happening behind closed doors and the moment my mom kicked me out he realized what he had ignored. I'm so thankful for him now and he constantly reminds me that no matter what happens he will always be there for me. But I will never have a mother and I have to live with the trauma I endured. I know for a fact that she will never come to any of my life achievements. I know for a fact that my dad loves me unconditionally but I also know he will never give me away if I choose to marry a girl. It helps to know I'm not the only one out there </3

snippet.textDisplay:
My mum's immediate family - my maternal grandparents, my aunt and her - got into JW when she was 3. My aunt - her older sister by four years - got kicked out of her home when she was 15 because she rebelled hard against all the rules. My mum did not leave until she was in her early 20s around the time she moved out, my grandpa left when he and my grandma got divorced and my grandma left when she was in her late 60s, so none of them are affiliated with JW anymore, thank god.

Unfortunately the fact that my mum was there from such an early age and stayed until her early 20s means that some of the stuff she was taught stuck. I came out to her as bi (now pan) when I was 17 and she told me straight to my face that she could tolerate it, but never accept it. As a result, I've not come out to my dad who is homophobic for other reasons more related to toxic masculinity and such. My mum, brother and grandma are the only people in my family who know (at least in terms of me coming out to them) and my grandma is the only person who knows that I'm nonbinary.


In contrast, my maternal grandma, the person who was the reason they got into the Witnesses in the first place, has been completely accepting of me being bi and nonbinary, but then again she also did not grow up getting indoctrinated like my mum did, plus one of the reasons she got snagged up by JW was that she was going through a severe post-partum depression and therefore was in a vulnerable state.


I'm so sorry, Hannah. The Witnesses are a horrible cult that has torn my family apart for decades and only now the damage is being somewhat fixed. My heart goes out to you and Ella, you should not have to deal with this from your own family members.

snippet.textDisplay: This was hard to watch. It's so sad,  I'm really sorry for you. You're nothing to be ashamed of, true words. You're a wonderful, beautiful person. You are you, and that's all you need. It's amazing that you still love your father though he has no love for you. It shows that you are a person with a good heart. Nevertheless your wedding will be wonderful. Don't let it become a sad day. At least for this one moment close the door behind you, and look forward. There is so much for you still. And perhaps one day your father sees what he has done, and if you still feel the love you open the door again. I wish you the happiest wedding day. Stay strong, live your life, love your life. ❤️

snippet.textDisplay: I can tell that you expected him not to come to your wedding..... so it isn’t the fact that he is not coming to the wedding, it is another nail in your heart that he didn’t choose you again. We can’t change everyone all at once but the one that does change may change another and you will notice your message starts a chain reaction of change. If your dad would have started with.... I love you.... and ended with I am sorry I can’t support this..... at least there would have been a sense that it is the church controlling his actions and not his heart if you could have at least heard “I love you” nobody wants to hear “I love you... but....” but at least if you heard that then there would have been a sense of hope you still matter to him. Now I am going to say that your happiness is in your own hands and what control you give people over that by allowing their acceptance to control your emotions will burden your heart and take away from your happiness. When the closed minded people see you happy, normal, and in control they may open up and have an epiphany and want to be a happy part of your life. We prove people wrong in their assumptions by doing/showing and not arguing or trying to hard to sway them verbally. That just may be to much “drama” for them and more so they want to stay removed from the situation. Kill them with kindness can work.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hannah, Ive been with you since the My Drunk Kitchen pizza episode where you ended up folding the pizza because it wouldn't cut, including dropping one of your crusts on the floor lol!
Im not going to say anything negative towards your Dad or his choices; because I don't want you to feel shitty about the relationship you have with him or the love you still have for him. My own Dad chooses to drink himself into oblivion and come in and out of my life when circumstances allow it. I'm not meaning to compare apples to oranges here. But, I'm familiar with how it feels to love someone who doesn't chose you put you first, or show up for the important moments in life that you want nothing more but to share with them. I'm sorry that you have to endure that feeling at all. Please take a bit of warmth out of this message, in knowing that someone you've never met from B.C Canada has your back, believes in your happiness, and is proud of the person you've become.
Thank you for everything over all these years. - Kelly O

snippet.textDisplay:
My family is religious too , not as religious as yours but I can totally relate to things like this.

I wish people would do more vids like this, religion has a lot of positives in society, but it can feel really isolating and anxiety inducing to be told that what you are is an abomination.

My parents totally disagree with any aspect of my transition, came out to them 3 years ago.

My dad still has never used my new name any time I visit he calls me my dead name. My mom goes into a crying fit and tries to convince me to stop transitioning every time that I come over.

My biggest regret is that the indoctrination really kept me from making friends let alone having relationships with people who were lgbt when I was younger. I had to overcome a lot of internalized transphobia

snippet.textDisplay: My cousin is a Jehovah's Witness and her mother calls her Bishop 'cause she's so strict about everything. snippet.textDisplay: Half of my family are JWs too. My grandmother refused to go to my mom and dad’s wedding as it was held in a Catholic Church. 25 ish years later, my grandmother is still part of the Witnesses, but she did attend my mom’s second wedding (although they were both remarrying and so Witnesses were officially “against” the marriage). It was not perfect, but I know it meant a lot to my mom that my grandma stepped outside of her “zone” to attend her second wedding. This story is to say, sometimes things change in little bits. I know my grandma was hurt equally that she could not attend my mom and dad’s wedding and when she had the chance to make another choice she did. She still reminds me I am not in the truth, but now we have totally random celebrations where family just happens to come together near the end of December. Sometimes people are not ready to jump in or out headfirst, but they can bend for you a little that shows they care.

snippet.textDisplay: Being hurt and let down by a parent is a slow burn. The hope I have for this person that I know to well is surprisingly bottomless and it fucking sucks. I know who I'm dealing with, yet every time they let me down it hurts so much and it surprises me how much it hurts because I know them, I knew they would do it again, eventually, I knew it was coming, so why does it hurt so fucking much. You'll always have hope for them, no matter how miniscule of an amount and even though you know they're an asshole, even though you wish it wasn't there. One day they might realize what they're doing and finally pick you, finally put me first instead of hurting me again, they might realize their mistakes, and that's why it hurts every time, because I expected someone who is so selfish and set in their ways to actually choose someone other than themselves for once. It still hurts.... You're not alone and it's not your fault, it's theirs.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have found that one of the most hurtful things in the world is being abandoned by your family. I know that it shouldn’t matter, but I can’t shake the knowledge that these people are biologically tied to me. Their blood runs through my veins. They raised me. They clothed me. They fed me. They celebrated every birthday with me. They gave me life. They gave me personality. They shaped, for better or for worse, who I am today. I love them. They love me.
But sometimes, love is conditional.
Sometimes, sharing the same blood isn’t enough.
Sometimes, there are thoughts and beliefs that will take precedence over you in the hearts and minds of your family.
Sometimes, they will love something more than they love you.
Knowing all of this does NOT make it any less hurtful. Being the black sheep, the ugly duckling, the puzzle piece that doesn’t fit; it is a constant sinking feeling in your chest of not belonging. It feels like your heart is being flayed in front of your own eyes. Every insult is a slice and every justification a tear.
When you’ve belonged to something your entire life, what are you supposed to do when they decide that you don’t “fit” anymore? That you’re straying from the path? You wake up in the dark, in the cold, and on an unfamiliar road with no one and nothing to help you find your way and guide you towards a new path. It’s devastating.

My heart goes out to any and all of you who are experiencing something like this. In time, the wounds will heal but I promise you, the scars will remain. I hope that you can find it within you to let them make you stronger rather than make you feel weak. You are not weak. You deserve happiness and love, and those who refuse to support you have no right to be in your life no matter who they are. Protect yourself. Love yourself. Do not be afraid to love other people in fear of what has happened in the past.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you so much for choosing to share this. You have far more power than you may feel in this situation. I have watched ex-witnesses on youtube, and I can't begin to imagine the horror of growing up in that world. But I have experienced parental rejection. It stings because even though it's not about who doesn't love you, they brought you here. It feels isolating, like you have no roots, no basline of support. And that's horrible. Can you function and otherwise be badass without it? Sure. You certainly did, my friend. But It sucks to have anyone attempt to invalidate you, especially when they're supposed to be your guide. Your first experience of the love this world has to offer. And it's a tension you can't erase. You can't fix it because it's not your fault and they won't listen. And You can't erase that connection. But you can move forward with all the people who love you, that small piece of hope,and self-honesty. Honest about the times, like now, when you need to let yourself feel sad or however about what's beyond your control. I so appreciate your bravery and integrity, sharing your human experience. So much love and Congratulations.  I read the description and I will be doing what I can to support ex witnesses, current and future.

snippet.textDisplay: Worse than scientology. Who knew? The most successful, insidious cults seem to be the ones that operate in plain sight. I used to think they (JWs) were just a nuisance that knocks on your door from time to time.  But when they (scientologists) got their hooks into someone I knew and cared about, I finally realized how dangerous they are. Every religion wants to dictate how you live your life, and who you may associate with. But there are a few, including the two aforementioned,  that take that to a level that classifies them as the clinical definition of a cult.

snippet.textDisplay: This hits so deep and is so closely rooted to home.. I was raised my entire life by a Jehovah’s Witness (my grandmother) and at the beginning I loved it but then as I got older I realized how ignorant I had become and later realized I had feelings for women. I came out at 13 and no one took me seriously, fastfoward to my early 20’s my aunt (my grandmothers daughter) came out and married a woman who served in the navy.. it became clear to my grandma that she was gay but she not once ever identified my aunts wife as just that.. she just called her, “that manly woman,” and they never spoke again.. fast forward again to now; I’m 25 and married to a woman who served in the military as well.. lol kind of the same story and I’ve been afraid to come out ever since but I’ve definitely gotten into heated debates w my grandmother and it continues to harm our relationship to this day and I just live in secret too afraid to even show my truth ..

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm always so disappointed when I hear about stories like this.

I was brought up JW (never believed in it), and I never experienced my parents controlling my life like that.
One of my siblings is gay and it's just whatever. My parents love my sibling's partner. My parents have reiterated that they love all of us no matter what and that something like that doesn't change who we are.

Not sure about my dad but my mum is baptised, and she and her family have been JW since way back.

Never been isolated from my family for not believing, other members have always been really lovely and helpful to me knowing full well that I don't believe, and they don't try and push it on me at all.

I'm not real keen on religion in general, but it's really sad that there are places in the world where JW is more of a cult than a religion.
It's really awful that you've had this experience.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have no idea if you'll see this, or if someone else will. I have no idea if this will help or hurt someone. But I'll say it on the off chance it may help.

The feeling of finality. The feeling of something finally being over, can go two ways, complete relief or complete destruction. It can be finally feeling the hold of an abusive partner leave, or it can be the sound of a heart monitor in a steady scream, signaling that someone you cherish is gone.

It is that final push to the end of an era. The abusive grip is finally gone. But where can you go now? What can you do with yourself? Will it happen again? The person you love is gone. How will you ever feel better? How long will it take? Can I ever feel completely whole?

The feeling of finality goes away, eventually. It takes time and self preservation. It hurts and it will do everything in its power to draw you back in. But eventually it will lose. You will get better.

It is the end of something, and another door will open for you eventually. The hallway between them may be dark and scary, with lots of corners and shadows that lurk behind you, but there will always be a light. Find solace in whatever you must. That will be the fuel to your lamp on the way. It may go out a couple, maybe even a thousand, times but eventually the flame will keep steady.

Something that helps me, personally, is actually a quote by John Lennon. "Everything will be okay in the end, if it's not okay, then it's not the end," If you don't like him, that's fine.

Find something that helps. You'll have to light your own lamp, but you can always ask for a match if you need one. Surround yourself with people who are willing to share their flame with you.

snippet.textDisplay: Much love for you Hannah. I appreciate your openness, and I wish you all the best. Take care of yourself first. I was raised in a church that I grew to realize was a cult, and I’ve had to choose between hiding large swaths of my life and personality from my family or risking isolation. I don’t talk to any of the “found family” and friends I made in high school anymore. Those people don’t get to enjoy the life I’ve made for myself, and I do my best every day not to feel guilty over that. I wish for myself and for you that one day the trauma will feel more distant, the songs that settled into us in our youth will fade, and that we will learn to be happy and healthy prioritizing ourselves and the families we’ve chosen.

snippet.textDisplay:
My wife's dad has never spoken to me and didn't come to our wedding. Four days before our wedding we got "an explanation" which was a condemnation letter on "jesus loves you" paper. They missed the most beautiful wedding, they've missed two brilliant grandchildren (Okay, biased, but omg, my kids are the cutest.) He (and his wife) have missed such a freaking amazing life. It took forever for me to get to the point where I didn't cry when I thought about my kids asking where their other papa was (never turned up, I have a great Step FIL), but now I just get sad for him. I can't wait to celebrate my kids joys.

snippet.textOriginal:
My wife's dad has never spoken to me and didn't come to our wedding. Four days before our wedding we got "an explanation" which was a condemnation letter on "jesus loves you" paper. They missed the most beautiful wedding, they've missed two brilliant grandchildren (Okay, biased, but omg, my kids are the cutest.) He (and his wife) have missed such a freaking amazing life. It took forever for me to get to the point where I didn't cry when I thought about my kids asking where their other papa was (never turned up, I have a great Step FIL), but now I just get sad for him. I can't wait to celebrate my kids joys. 


You are a beautiful person who will have a beautiful wedding. Love will drip for it. And hey, I can be your dad. A 36 year old Jewish girl fits that, right?

snippet.textDisplay:
I've been around Witnesses my entire life (most of my mom's family are baptized as such).
Anytime I watch people's videos on them I get so confused at how their congregations run.
I've never heard of Witnesses not being connected to Christianity because they see themselves as Christians because the follow the teachings of Christ and his Apostles.
My family is far from how other's are. No one has shunned the very out Lesbian, Bi, and third genders in my family. No one shunned the Military serving and no one shunned the premarital relation/children havers. No one cast away the non believers and non practicers. No one took issue with my head-to-toe tattooed husband. I feel bad that these are the versions of Witnesses others have known because I have never met one.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Why am I surprised? Why am I upset?"
I asked those same questions when my dad didn't show up to come see me in the hospital or when I send him tickets to come see any of my performances.
You have every right to be upset. Getting married is a big deal, something that many hope will bring the ones they love together in a time of celebration. It's perfectly understandable to have a small part of yourself hope that your dad would come, even if you know that won't happen. To be blatantly rejected by someone you love, who is supposed to love you unconditionally is a pain I wouldn't wish on anyone. I will never understand how someone would choose a religion/cult that demands so much from you over your fucking child.

snippet.textDisplay: I understand your pain, truly I do. I was born into being a Jehovah’s Witness. I got babtized at 15. It wasn’t until my late 20’s I decided to leave and be true to myself.  I was disfellowshipped. Few years later I came out to my parents as gay. They told me they cannot be in my life anymore. It took years of extreme heartache, pain, anger and utter feeling of abandonment to finally let go of it all and be happy. After all that is what I fought for in the first place, to be myself and happy. It was a long painful journey but I’m happily married to my beautiful wife. And to my surprise my mom reached out few weeks ago and we have been talking almost everyday. It took 10 years!! I hope your dad will come around one day but for your own sanity and happiness, don’t count on it. Get married, be happy and live your life to the fullest Sweety. You are responsible for your own happiness. No one else! ❤️

snippet.textDisplay:
My ex-wife's mother was a Jehovah's Witness. Fyi, I'm female. Her mother hated me, because I was "keeping her daughter gay"...
When my MIL was dying, literally on her deathbed, in her last conversation (via phone) with her daughter, she told her that she was 'an abomination', that she was 'unnatural', and told her how devastated she was that they would never see each other in the rapture, because of her daughter's sin.
It was horrible, and she (my ex) was destroyed by her mother's behavior and words.
She was a terrible mother and a hate-filled person who used her 'faith' to hurt her family... her straight daughter, gay daughter and gay son. She was a POS.

snippet.textDisplay: My heart breaks for you and your raw emotion here. My brother and  I have been completely estranged from our biological father for almost 30 years now, although for different reasons than yours.  But the hurt and rejection were awful, just the same. Eventually I got past it hurting and life is so much better since I realized we are his loss, he isn't ours.  He has missed our adult lives and will never meet his grandchildren. He has missed out on all the love and joy of this family all this time, but I'm not missing having a crazy person in my life.  We have a wonderful stepdad who's loved us for 45 years and counting.  So go live your life, have a long, happy marriage and surround yourself with people who make you happy.  It's ok to be sad about your dad, but someday I hope you get to this point of knowing this is his loss, not yours. Best wishes ♥️

snippet.textDisplay: Generalizing Witnesses like that is pretty awful. My stepmother was born and raised as a witness. She has been a member as long as she can remember, I am an atheist, my dad is a strict Roman Catholic, she’s never been excommunicated and she’s found a way to balance her faith and her love for family. Blaming all this on Jehovah Witnesses is pretty short sighted of you, maybe you’re just hurt and it’s easier for you to blame a denomination than to just hold your dad accountable for his ignorance. I can say whole heartedly though, my stepmom is very devout but still manages to let’s us all know everyday how much we are loved.
